sn54.6:4.4: “Mendicants, do you develop mindfulness of breathing?”
sn54.6:4.5: When he said this, Venerable Ariṭṭha said to him:
sn54.6:4.7: “But mendicant, how do you develop it?”
sn54.6:4.8: “Sir, I’ve given up desire for sensual pleasures of the past. I’m rid of desire for sensual pleasures of the future. And I have eliminated perception of rigidity regarding phenomena internally and externally.
sn54.6:4.9: Ever mindful, I will breathe in. Mindful, I will breathe out.
sn54.6:4.10: That’s how I develop mindfulness of breathing.”
sn54.6:5.1: “That is mindfulness of breathing, Ariṭṭha; I don’t deny it.
sn54.6:5.2: But as to how mindfulness of breathing is fulfilled in detail, listen and pay close attention, I will speak.”
sn54.6:6.1: “And how is mindfulness of breathing fulfilled in detail?
sn54.6:6.2: It’s when a mendicant—gone to a wilderness, or to the root of a tree, or to an empty hut—sits down in the meditation posture, with their body erect, and establishes mindfulness right there.
sn54.6:6.3: Ever mindful, they breathe in. Mindful, they breathe out.
sn54.6:6.4: Breathing in deep they know: ‘I’m breathing in deep.’ …
sn54.6:6.5: They practice like this: ‘I’ll breathe in observing letting go.’ They practice like this: ‘I’ll breathe out observing letting go.’
sn54.6:6.6: This is how mindfulness of breathing is fulfilled in detail.”
